Description: Black and white granite amuletic figure in the form of the goddess Taweret standing on an oblong plinth, with back-pillar transversely pierced for suspension. The surfaces are smooth with only basic modelling of the features, due probably to the hardness of the material; the arms are so slightly represented as to be almost undetectable.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Provenance not specified in the Museum register, but possibly from Tell Dafana, as suggested by the context of the item in the list. However, the "Taurt of grey syenite " mentioned W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 73 § 70 should be London, BM, EA 20658, clearly from Tell Dafana according to the Museum register.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 73 § 70) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.62-63, p.180, pl.22)
